Fall damage is too high, and every tip to avoid is is inconsistent. Grappling hook didn't come out and my cloud in a bottle didn't work. The jump was used up on leaving the vine or, somethin, I don't know. What I do know is, fall damage is too high in this game. It was a medium core and right next to my base, basically no consequence other then losing 6 stars. Nothin, less then nothin, but I would like to play a hardcore character, and I shouldn't because of this bullshit. It's just too damn high. I wasn't even at the top of my houses roof in terms of height and had over 200 hp. It's too damn high. Good news everyone. They added a bunch of items to reduce or eliminate fall damage! I still feel like fall damage itself is a bit overturned though. Also anyone else feel like traps just make the game less fun? They're easy enough to avoid really, but, what's the point exactly? Cause you just get a light(helmet magiluminescence) and hold a dart trap as you dash through the cavern. Easy enough, but it's tedious, and not fun, why are they here exactly? There's also now an item that just lets you see all wires at all times. Traps now essentially just give you vision....well, that's, okay I guess. Makes them feel even more pointless now though.  Also, I like fishing but, doesn't anyone else feel like it's too important and strong? So much good stuff comes from it. Too much even. Well most of it doesn't scale into late game, I suppose....
Its great its so much fun and its challenging and they're is so much you can do you can play this game for hours and not be bored

[h1] Terraria - It's a Gem [/h1]

[b] This is my experience of this game. Make of that what you will. [/b]

[list] 

[*] There are lot of objectives to complete with an insane amount of items and achievements to collect. 
[*] The combat is enjoyable - not the greatest but not bad in any sense in my opinion.
[*] Character and world progression feels is solid. There are so many different ways to play.
[*] If you somehow manage to do and collect everything in the game you can still get hundreds to thousands of hours out of the building aspect of the game.
[*] There are rare items you can farm for which is enjoyable to me, and it feels very good when the loot you're after finally drops.
[*] The mechanisms of how items work in this game is interesting to me, you can tell a lot of work was put in to make every item feel like it has purpose, which is unbelievable because there are over five thousand items - a lot of variety there. 
[*] The world generation is unpredictable enough, and you never know what you're going to find in it.
[*] You can find and meet interesting characters that will help, and sell items to you by having them live in a house, castle, town or city that you've constructed for them.
[*] I enjoy what atmosphere this game has. Just coming across a little pond with dragonflies hovering over water lilies during the day, or being inside of your home in the evening with fireflies surrounding it as an owl sits on the roof you built can feel like the time you've spent adventuring was worth it. The world feels alive.
[*] The music is iconic. There are a lot of cool tracks, and they're adding more. My favorite track is Underground Jungle.
[*] The boss fights are intimidating and fun accompanied by intense music to fit.
[*] There's a huge variety of enemies as well as a huge variety of ways to fight them.
[*] It has a crafting system with crafting trees that can take time to make useful items for your character, but it's rewarding.
[*] The UI is clean - easy to understand.
[*] The developers are still updating the game free of charge. The game is only $10 and often goes on sale for $5. I bought Terraria on its release, and had no idea just to how great of a purchase that was going to be.
[*] It has a great modding community, and support if you somehow want more out of this game.

[/list]

[b] The team at Re-Logic actually cares and listens to feedback, and are real gamers like us which is why I believe this product is so successful. I can't say the same for most of the AAA industry today. [/b]

Terraria: A Pixelated Paradise of Infinite Adventure!

Terraria isn't just a game; it's an odyssey into the depths of boundless creativity and exploration. From the moment you step foot into its pixelated world, you're greeted with a sense of wonder and excitement that's rarely matched in the gaming realm.

The beauty of Terraria lies in its sheer diversity of experiences. Whether you're delving into the depths of caverns in search of rare ores, battling colossal bosses that test your skill and strategy, or constructing intricate structures that defy imagination, there's always something new and exhilarating to discover.

One of the most captivating aspects of Terraria is its sandbox nature. The freedom to shape and mold the world to your liking is unparalleled. Want to build a towering castle in the sky? Go for it. Prefer to dig deep underground and create a sprawling underground metropolis? The choice is yours. With a vast array of building materials and tools at your disposal, the only limit is your imagination.

But Terraria isn't just about building and exploration; it's also about the thrill of adventure. The game is filled with an assortment of challenging enemies and formidable bosses that will put your combat skills to the test. Whether you're facing off against the mighty Eye of Cthulhu or Going deep into the catacombs to find treasure. Every encounter is a pulse-pounding adrenaline rush.

What truly sets Terraria apart, however, is its sense of community. Whether you're teaming up with friends to tackle a difficult boss or sharing your latest creations with the world, there's a vibrant and welcoming community of players ready to embrace you with open arms.

In conclusion, Terraria is a masterpiece of gaming innovation. With its limitless creativity, thrilling exploration, and strong sense of community, it's a game that will keep you coming back for more time and time again. So grab your pickaxe, sharpen your sword, and prepare for the adventure of a lifetime. Terraria awaits, and the journey is just beginning.

[b] My Suggestion & Wish-List for Terraria [/b]
- Zenith Tier weapons (i.e. a "zenith" for each class with a difference in how they work and what their damage focus is (wave vs single target vs crowd control etc). which is better than just a reskin! 
- Being able to favorite (or lock) slots in other inventories (i.e chests, maybe always 1 item will be left, etc)
- a post-moonlord "moonlord", maybe even "barely undefeatable" and more like a score gauge -> how quick can you kill it. no loot drops, just a relic or trophy. 
- another difficulty -> harder than mastermode, maybe legendary mode? maybe even with sliders to tweak it. 
- you should be able to put the familiar set on womenquins/mannequins and set their things (hair, color etc.) so they are actually more than just "armor stands"
- more hair styles
- an actually working "color selection" on certain things, esp. skin colors are very hard to do and the actually colors are quite jumpy/limited 
- a better alignment of early game ores (the 3 new ones just seem better, esp. platinum vs gold)
- early game ore gate-ing like its with the HM ores. currently you just dig down and get platinum/gold. no real need to get tier 1 or 3. Lead/Iron is useful for rails and for the anvil, if you dont find them. 
- summon count under the icon (or when you mouse over, i.e. 5/7)
- alignment of the permanent buffs. currently summoner is absolute OP (as it is quite early to get pre HM and is a dps boost on all classes). it feels that mage and range are just neglected, as those buff items are HM. 
- rework / rebalancing (maybe?) of the biome chest drops. esp. the non-generic ones feel absolutely underwhelming. rainbow is god-tier and even on moonlord useful. the hydra is a decent sentry (also universally useful). the piranha gun is good, but absolutely underwhelming at this point, esp. compared to other best-in-class items you get around the same time. the vampire blades are a god-send on melee (or maybe useful as a general healing item) but otherwise very underwhelming. the the corruptor is... its good-ish? but again, same with the piranha gun. class items on the same tier are just better. the tiger staff... either its the AI or the damage, but overall it feels like it should be barely after HM start, not post plantera... at least for me it feels weak. 
- rebalancing / improving summon AI. currently there is no need to use all summons or to upgrade. some are S-tier and you can just skip the rest...

You will not be disappointed. BUY THIS GAME!!!!!!!!!!!

loved this game for years; always gets better with every update.

A truly beautiful piece of pixel art, over the years it has earned the title of 'yeah this game's cool' and cool it is. There is a plethora of minerals, animals, bosses and enemies to find/collect/mine/defeat and yet none of it feels overwhelming. 

My personal favourite feature is the npc's that wander the earth, overtime creating a community of wonderfully colourful characters. It almost distracts you from the fact that in the real world you will never feel any truly satisfying sense of achievement, never to form any real bonds, and of course one day becoming nothing but teeth and bones, name carved into stone that no one will want to visit or even remember a couple generations later. That is assuming you have you have a loving partner and kids, which you won't... because you play terraria.

Story time: 

So I'm on a mediumcore character with a master (w/e max mode is) setting on a large map with the purple dingy. Anyhoo. So I have this minion trinken and she's a lovely ghost that tickles things to death. Whelp she was a great income sorce for zombies on nights when they'd bang on my door. Good source of coinage for starters cause I do nothing right? Oh no. So see just moments before this comment a random "blood" zombie event happened that night. I got finessed thinking I could fend them all off. Nope. Game said "Hey bubby we see you're struggling but in a good way here's a way to adapt and suffer more." Before these zombies I was vaguely near the purple dingy area. I heard a background worm.........I have iron armor. I thought "maybe it's a medium one and we can shrug it off."

Nope, game said "here have a biggin for no reason." ~ Death

11 things you probably need to know about the game

1. The start is really hard, I almost refunded it because of this.
2. Make a platform grinding area in the sky to kill the eye of Cthulhu.
3. Make houses and use the housing query to see if its valid for NPCs to live in it, After that you can buy stuff from them.
4. To use hooks press E.
5. To get rid of mounting effects right click on them at the top left.
6. Destroy demon altars in the corruption to get blessed with more ores, like Palladium and Chlorophyte.
7. Most worm type creatures can only move in the earth blocks and jump out of the ground.
8. There are cloud looking islands in the sky with loot, Called Floating Islands.
9. Hardmode is forced onto your world after killing the wall of flesh.
10. To summon the wall of flesh you need guide voodoo doll and throw it into the lava at hell located really far into the ground.
11. Use the fandom if you find something you dont know about

this game has almost zero flaws, you have literally no reason to dislike it. it's cheap, fun, has an insane amount of positive reviews, and is frankly one of the best games you can get for this price. go ahead and purchase it and play for a little while, if you dislike it you can always end up refunding it (which i doubt anyone will do). no normal person dislikes terraria. i heavily recommend this to be played with friends, though.

[b]Why to Buy?[/b]
             There are few games with such a good cost/content ratio. For the price point it's hard to beat.
The amount of content is ever expanding with new versions that add to the game considerably.
[i]*Many of the new features are/were directly inspired by the community*[/i]
Devs are also actively involved in the community and really do care about their game.
Though sometimes updates take a while they are never disappointing and add a ton to the game.
Not only that there are tons of ways to mod it.

[b]GO BUY IT![/b]
Stop being cheap it's 10 bucks.

[b]Complaints?[/b] [i](I am stretching here, there are no real complaints from me)[/i]    
            Worlds are finite.
            To get certain things in the game, you have to make more than one world.

Terraria is overall an excellent experience and wildly fun to play and explore with lots to do, it will keep you coming back. And back.
And then you think: what would be fun to play for a little while before I have to do [insert task]?
And then you're back.

This game just has so much love put into it, from the reference to other games to the amount of content given all of which they never made to pay extra for, while it is still being updated. I probably come back to it at least once every year. You can build structures, obtain crazy items that rely on a drop-based system, create a build that goes with the class you have chosen and then in an instant swap to different items to change your class. This game has 33 bosses and around 5000+ items to obtain, not including the mods from the community that probably triples the length of the game and all of the items. The only issue this game has is that you'll use the wiki a lot to find how to get some items or how to progress since its a decent sized game but once you have played it you most likely remember it and come back for more.

I mean, I don't really know what else there is to say.  The game is incredible, there's so much content and things to do, the replay value is insane, the modding scene is also insane, and it's honestly one of the best sandbox games ever made.  If you haven't played it, you're doing yourself a disservice.

edit 2/21/24:

Now that I've fully completed the game by myself, I think I can give an actual review now. First things first, and if you haven't played Terraria, you will be hearing this a lot: it's definitely not for everyone. You'll be relying on the wiki and other external sources to get you through because this game does NOT hold your hand. It took me a year and a half to even get back into the game after first buying it because I had literally no idea what to do. But, oh man, when I got back into it... I was just addicted.

Once you get past the initial phase of confusion, this game is amazing. The progression is the star of the show, really, because it's so easy to become enamored with getting to that next big goal. Even then, there's still a lot of creative things you can do with your world, seeing as it IS a sandbox game. But that core gameplay loop is what makes Terraria special. The controls are easy to understand (mostly), and I had no tech issues when playing it (I assume it can run on a potato, but if your PC really sucks then you might have issues).

Cons: crawltipede

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Terraria is similar to Minecraft. Both were officially released in 2011 but Minecraft had released in earlier versions in 2009. The objective of the game is varied, allowing players to choose how they want to play the game. The most important ones are kill the final boss Moon Lord, Empress of Light and other top-tier Hardmode bosses.

Gameplay-wise, mouse and keyboard. 

Many things to do in Terraria. The generic loop is survive, kill monsters/bosses, mine, craft, get new weapons and armour rinse and repeat.

Logic Gates. You can even build your own mini-computer within. Not that I actually bothered.

Bosses. If you can kill a boss, the boss loot is stronger, upgrades you and can be used to easily kill the same boss repetitively.

Arenas. They don't exist in game, you have to build them. Before you beat a boss, you are generally significantly weaker than the boss stat-wise. You need to build special arenas that will give you a major terrain advantage and make killing the boss easier. Once you kill the boss, the boss loot will greatly improve your tools.

Crafting. You need a guide for this. The UI for crafting is also horrible. You can't craft from items in your boxes, you have to extract them, stand at a specific crafting station and then the recipe option will appear.

Fishing. Not the best model. You just need a 15*20 pool of water to begin fishing. You can't see the fish and the fish always magically appear if you have bait.

Conclusion, do try Terraria. While the game is annoying at times and extremely beginner unfriendly, Terraria is easily playable with a guide.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Arena Building
NOT WORLDBUILDING. Instead of the traditional enter a boss' arena, fight and try to win, players have to "cheese" the boss by building an arena to beat the boss with. It's like military infrastructure meant to kill a boss.

2. Cheese Tricks
Generally, weapons are picked on the damage that they deal. The greater the damage, the more likely you pick it. However, you can find little "cheeses". Like using dynamite to kill the Destroyer.

3. Multiplayer
The ability to play with others and explore a randomly procedurally generated world. It's not that big a plus considering that every world has exactly the same bosses in the exact same order.

4. Interesting Bosses
Wall of Flesh was interesting.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. No Puzzles
No real solving on your own. The Dungeon Guardian wasn't a puzzle. It just blocked you.

2. Constant Spawning of Monsters
It's not actually fun to have to constantly swat bats/mosquitoes.

3. Puddle Fishing
Quest Slave. Not the best part of the game. You can't see the fish in the water and you're just miraculously getting fish from a puddle.

4. Inflation Creep
As the higher level items come to you, the old stuff is either junk or has to be combined to make special items. Items that can't be combined are essentially junk.

5. Disappointing Dungeons
Kind of straightforward paths with traps. No hidden secrets, just a maze with a boss to "cheese" at the end.


6. Sky Islands are Dull
Just clouds with 1 house. I was expecting more.

[h1][b]NEUTRAL[/b][/h1]
1. Reliance on Guides
I didn't like the idea of consistently looking for the answer from an online guide. It broke the experience of figuring out what the developer could design for you i.e. Andrew “Redigit“ Spinks. Yet, guides did make things move more smoothly and helped me to realize the Dungeon Guardian couldn't be killed normally.

2. Weapon / Armour Crafting
Fun to figure out that in order to beat the next boss you have to craft stronger stuff for mobility, armour and damage.  Boring because it's the same formula over and over again. Pretty much all the higher level/damage items can be used to kill the boss. Some are just slightly faster.

There isn't a specialty weapon that is the weakness of any boss or has a special utility function in-game.

3. Building a House
Why is it so complicated? Make a Table, Make a chair, Make walling, tile the place, make sure it's surrounded and not corrupted. WTF. No wonder the online guide creates pet boxes.

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Fishing With Fish
See the fish. Ensure that the source water has to exceed an even bigger size?

2. Fishing with bait
You have a Meat Grinder and Rotten Meat. I assumed you could grind the Rotten Meat into chum that could be turned into bait. No. The Meat Grinder doesn't do much at all.

3. Ensure everything has a Role
All the food can be turned into some sort of meal/potion with some special unique add-on. Sell it to a trader's market for coin. At the start of the game, you need a sizeable amount of coin to buy all the necessary equipment, wire and tools.

4. Ships/AirShips/Balloons + Increase Air Height
Space should be much higher. Much much higher. I think the game can expand into distant lands. First by floating boat, then by airship.

It's finally over (the stupid achievement hunt)! I am never going to play this game again.

Building is probably the best part but serves no purpose after some point (when you have several bunkers connected with teleporters all over the world).

Some boss fights are OK (Plantera, Golem). Building arenas for boss fights kind of feels like cheating but most can not be defeated without one. At least not on expert difficulty.

The fishing quest is kind of fun. I greatly suggest journey mode if you plan to do it.

What's bad:
[list]
[*] mining ores is extremely grindy
[*] combat is as basic as it can get
[*] item bloat; every single enemy drops so much crap
[*] art style, especially characters and humanoid enemies (not talking about graphics, I don't mind pixel art)
[*] the soundtrack - it's so annoying it's hard to rationally describe; I especially hate the opening theme (the one you hear immediately after starting a new game)
[*] sound effects
[*] the feeling of discovery and adventure just isn't there (unless you consider digging various colors of dirt an adventure)
[/list]

Terraria is a pixelated wonderland of endless possibilities. From the moment I dug my first block, I was hooked on this sandbox adventure. The sheer diversity of biomes, creatures, and items is mind-boggling, creating a sense of exploration that never gets old.

The freedom to build and shape the world to my liking is empowering. Whether delving into treacherous caverns or summoning otherworldly bosses, Terraria's blend of creativity and action is addictive. The progression is rewarding, with each new discovery opening up a realm of exciting opportunities.

The multiplayer experience adds another layer of enjoyment. Collaborating with friends to conquer challenges or simply explore the vast world together enhances the game's charm. The retro aesthetic, combined with the depth of gameplay, makes Terraria a timeless classic in the sandbox genre.

In summary, Terraria is a digital canvas where your imagination can run wild. It's not just a game; it's a journey of discovery and creation that keeps drawing me back in.

Have you ever wanted to build your own world, filled with wonders and challenges that test your creativity and endurance? Look no further than Terraria, an amazing sandbox game that takes you on a journey through different worlds as you explore, build, fight, and craft your way to success.

Terraria is a 2D sandbox survival game that combines elements of open-world exploration, crafting, and monster-fighting. The game is set on a fictional, procedurally generated 2D world that you can customize and craft to your liking. You can explore vast open landscapes, build your own structures, and fight off a vast array of monsters and bosses. The game offers a wide variety of weapons, tools, and armour for you to create, ranging from simple wooden swords and axes to intricate magic staves and powerful ranged weapons.

But what makes Terraria truly special is its creative potential. The game offers a vast array of blocks, from common dirt and stone to rare and unique blocks like ash and marble, and even floating crystals and cloud blocks. These blocks can be used to create almost anything your imagination can fathom. Want to build a grand castle or a majestic temple? Go ahead. Want to build a sprawling city or a peaceful village? You can do that too. The possibilities are truly endless.

But the game is not just about building. It is also about combat and survival. The game is filled with an endless array of dangerous NPCs, monsters, and bosses to face, ranging from simple jellyfish and slime to giant bee queens and giant flying eyes. These enemies can drop rare loot and valuable tools that you can use to progress further in the game. There are also a ton of unique events and challenges to face, such as invasions of zombies and skeletons or blood moons and solar eclipses, all of which offer their own unique rewards and challenges.

Terraria's gameplay loop is also incredibly addictive, thanks to the abundance of loot and tools to craft. Once you start playing, you will find yourself hooked, spending hours exploring, fighting, crafting, and building, all in the pursuit of better loot and more powerful tools. Each time you create a powerful new weapon or piece of armour, you will feel a sense of satisfaction, knowing that your efforts have paid off. And the game is just as much fun alone as it is with friends, offering both single-player and multiplayer modes that are both equally enjoyable.

If you are looking for a game that provides the ultimate creative and challenging experience, then look no further than Terraria. With its vast open world, limitless building possibilities, and vast array of enemies and events, you will find yourself lost in its world for hours on end. It is a game that will keep you coming back for more, time and time again, as you strive to create even more amazing structures, collect even more powerful weapons and tools, and face even more challenging enemies.

In short, Terraria is a game that offers something for everyone, whether you are a seasoned gamer or a beginner. It is easy to learn but hard to master, so you will find yourself constantly learning new tricks and techniques to help you advance further in the game. And even if you are not typically a fan of sandbox games, Terraria offers such a rich and rewarding experience that it is hard not to love. So, if you are looking for a game that truly offers it all, look no further than Terraria.

11/10. Been playing ever since it came to Xbox 360, never stopped or grown tired of it. There's a reason it won the "Labor of Love" award and is one of the highest grossing games of all time. If you've already played the base game a lot and are looking for something new try the following mods: Calamity, Thorium, Fargo's Souls Mod, and Spirit Mod. If you've done all that i suggest either searching for more mods/mod-packs that catch your eye or do self imposed challenges vanilla or modded such as: Only one class, Hardcore, No armor, or more crazy stuff like: No jumping, No movement accessories, etc. Seriously could be anything just have fun!

Initially played this on Xbox 360 but later got it on PC. I forget how I got this game, but I think I got it from Xbox gold way back when (2012?). At first, like many people who first picked up Terraria, I thought it was 2D Minecraft. I later realized how wrong I was. Sure they share similar aspects like mining and building, but Terraria is more progression based.

I think the best part of Terraria as a kid was that there were so many different items and yet I was able to memorize them all and what they all did because I looked at the wiki and learned what each thing did. Even now I can recall what some of the items do because I loved the game so much I basically studied it.

What I loved about Terraria was that exploration is always unique. From exploring the Crimson to structures underground to other biomes to exploring floating islands, Terraria always had something to offer. There are so many different weapons, tools, and armor so everything always felt fresh and like there was a progression and things to work towards.

But what I loved the most was the fact that you had to fight bosses to progress, and the fact that there are so many bosses amazed me, being a kid that only played Minecraft, which had like two bosses. It was also awesome how NPCs appeared in your world and I was always excited whenever one did, and getting geared to fight bosses and getting magic weapons that do so much cool stuff was awesome.

There is always something to do in Terraria, more than most games. I really wish I could say more but I don't know what to say because Terraria is just that great. Who knows I might come back to this review to add more if I ever think of it.

People used to call this "2D Minecraft", however I feel like that is doing a disservice to just how unique Terraria is. Gameplay is much more focused around collecting gear and using it to fight bosses, similar to a classic Zelda. Yes, there is block based building and mining but it is hardly the focus of the game like is in Minecraft. If you like 2D platformers and gear based adventure games, this is for you.

There's a reason this game is so highly rated. It's one of the pioneers of the modern survival sandbox genre. This game genuinely has one of the best progression systems I've ever seen in a video game, and even over 10 years later still remains one of the greatest survival sandbox experiences on Steam. If Steam had a "must play" category, Terraria would definitely be on there.

Oh, and the game has official mod support endorsed by the devs. But I won't touch on that rabbit hole here.

God i honestly cannot describe how much i love this game. I have spent WAY over 1000 hours, and i don't regret. One. Single. Hour. There is SO MUCH TO DO! Oh, you beat the game? Beat it with only magic weapons. Did that? Melee. That too? Do it yoyo, then only ranged. Then only bows, then only guns! Bored of fighting? Build something cool! Or/and play with friends! 

I don't think I will ever get truly tired of this game, but after probably a combined 2400 hours it has gotten stale to play solo. Not with friends tho, I still have a blast with that. And modding is also a fresh and super fun experience. EVEN better with friends. 

And that's not to mention that the amazing and genuinely kind devs just won't stop adding new content! Last big update my ass, you've said that for like 5 years lmao 

See you all in Terraria 2 after 1.6 comes out and it's ACTAULLY the last big update.

Super exciting game. I usually write kinda bad reviews but I'll try and do good this time.

. The game is super chill, unless you're doing something dangerous you should be able to just casually play without a care in the world. I would recommend trying to do something interesting every like hour or so. Maybe search for a specific item in a chest, loot the underworld for some risk and reward type action, or just build something beautiful. And you should know it's beautiful, because you made it.

. Boss fights are also pretty relaxing to be quite frank. Unless you are in I'd say...post...Plantera? Maybe? Post-Plantera and up progression starts to get a tad more stressful, as the bosses hit harder, so your weapons need to do the same. (I would recommend trying to get the Possessed Hatchet from Golem. It's actually REALLY good for the Lunatic Cultist and Duke Fishron!)

. Go on little mining expeditions every once in a while. You would not believe how absolutely gorgeous the game's cave systems tend to be. Especially in those glowing moss areas they added recently. You'll find some top-notch pixel art there.

. If you find this whole experience too...chill. Too calm. Play Calamity on Tmodloader, version 2.2. If that still seems too little of a challenge, add a little mod called Infernum. Pre-hardmode progression may seem easy...but the instant you enter hardmode...your life will become a living nightmare. Bosses take hours to beat because you keep dying to 123 damage from the destroyer's lasers, Plantera almost one-shots you on contact. If you manage to not rage quit in time to beat moon lord, you will regret that decision. The quadruplets of destruction and agony, Supreme Calamitas, Devourer of Gods, Jungle Dragon Yharon, and finally...Draedon and his toys of destruction known as the Exo Mechs. These four will be your doom in the end, no matter what you will not defeat them without some kind of outsider help.

That concludes my analysis of this game! To conclude I wish you the best in trying out this game, it will calm your nerves and senses to the most fine of standards. The game provides a nice and peaceful serenity, as long as you keep your world in check. 

-Sincerely, A Random Artist.

Terraria is definitely one of my favourite games of all time! I've been playing on and off since 2015 when I was quite a young child (i actually met a great friend of mine because of it :3), and I've loved it ever since! Few other games have managed to make me interested in every little detail and inspire me to create things of my own in and outside the game as much as Terraria has.

If you've not seen Terraria before, I'd describe it as a sandbox adventure game with an emphasis on combat, set in a world that evolves as you progress. Although it is often compared to it, Terraria has quite a key difference to Minecraft - Terraria is a lot more progression driven, where as in Minecraft the player often sets their own goals. The player is still allowed to progress as they please, but if you're a Minecraft player who was looking for a similar player-set progression system, Terraria might not be for you.

The freedom for the player to shape the world and build what they choose, diverse combat system, the well-designed boss fights and the diverse and ever-changing world are my favourite elements of Terraria. The only real things that I dislike about Terraria is that you may have to grind a bit at points (especially at higher difficulties) and sometimes the game can start to feel a little tedious, especially near the end of a really long playthrough or if you're doing a few playthroughs in a row.

Despite my minor problems with it, I still see Terraria as an almost completely perfect game! If you've never played Terraria before I would very highly recommend it - it's worth far more than even it's full price!

A Reveww of Terrawriah

As an olde man who struglez with dysleksia, navigatin the vast wurld of gaming kahn be quite the challange. But wen I stumbuled upon "Terrawriah," I wuz both intriqued and perplexed. The game promissed adventur and kreativity, but wat I encowntered wuz a bewlidering maze of piksels and confyujsion.

Firstly, let me tell yu about the grafiks. Oh, the grafiks! They're like a mishmash of colors and shaypes, swirling around like a tornado in a paint factory. Tryin to make sens of wats happening on the screen is like tryin to reed a book with the pages all out of ordur.

Then there's the gameplay. You're dropped into this wurld with no instrukshuns, no guidans wotsoevur. It's like bein thrown into a river without knowing how to swim. I stumbuled around, swingin my sword at nuthin in particuler, hopin to fend off watevr monsters lurked in the shadows.

And dont evun get me started on the crafting system. I kudn't figure out how to make anythin more complex than a wooden sword. Evry time I tryd to kombin items, it was like tryin to solve a puzzle with missin pieces.

But despite all these frustrashuns, there was sumthin oddly captivating about Terrawriah. Maybe it wuz the sens of explorashun, or the thrill of stumblin upon hidden treasures. Or maybe it wuz just the satisfackshun of finally defeetin a boss after countlus failed attemps.

In the end, Terrawriah may not be the most aksesibul game for sumwon like me, but it sertinly has its charms. So if you're willin to overlook its shortcomins and embrase the kaos, then maybe, just maybe, you'll find sumthin to luv in this quirky littul wurld.

[h1]Survival optional, Conquest eventual - A towering wall of a benchmark, fleshed out with content.[/h1]

Terraria has been a game to come back to over and over. Originally playing at launch, I found myself lost in a newly created world, to build a home and explore. New enemies in every area, and Zelda-style items to help my spelunking efforts. 

At night time, monsters will come out, and you will need to stay safe, so first you will need to build a shelter. Venturing down into the depths of the world will face you against new enemies, which to survive, you'll need to learn new tactics. you'll come across new weapons from enemy drops, and from loot containers. This was when I first noticed the similarities with old rpg's. I'd found a boomerang! "Swish" I thought.

[h1]Now I was a boomerang wielding, sword swinging, base building powerhouse![/h1]

What I felt was a major turning point for me, had allowed me to gather more resources, add extra wings to my manor, and build a 'hook-shot' style grappling hook. Things were going well, so I decided to venture deeper in the world. The enemies were harder, but I had my boomerang, and with some sharp reflexes, I was able to stand my ground. I needed a more powerful weapon to continue.

And there it was... I could hear the chest opening sound from Legend of Zelda in my head as I hovered my mouse over the item, and I read the reassuring words in true old-school RPG format....

[h1]You have found a FLAMARANG![/h1]

Filled with excitement, I threw my boomerang away. It came back. "I should have expected that". I equipped my new Flamarang, and travelled downward into the unknown. I found a giant blue glowing mushroom biome, and a lava lake with obsidian towers. Amazed, I ended up building a giant fortress, digging to the bottom of the world, had some NPC's move into my house, and spent almost 90 hours find new things, before eventually, moving onto a new adventure in a different game.

Moving forward 6 years, I found myself in a relationship, with an actual woman. She barely played any games, but I showed her Terraria, and she instantly fell in love with it. Now we play together, and most of my past experience has become redundant. As I understand it, now there are at least over 20 bosses, and I'm fairly confident that there are lots more than that, still for me to find. There’s also quite a large amount of resource tiers, so you’ll always be upgrading, and when you think you’re done…

[h1] BAM… Hardmode. And you get to do it all over again.[/h1]

Over the 6 years that I'd not played Terraria, content has been added almost constantly. Now we're playing what feels like a new game together. The first time I played, I think I found three bosses, and only managed to kill two of them. 

If you want my advice...

[h1]Grow a beard, find a friend, play Terraria, and become more awesome.[/h1]

Terraria is not just a game; it's an obsession. With over 600 hours clocked, I can confidently say it's a masterpiece that never gets old. Whether you're a warrior, a wizard, a ranger, or a summoner, Terraria offers a unique experience that caters to every play style. The thrill of exploring vast bio mes, conquering bosses, and the endless possibilities of building keep me coming back for more. It's a world where every play through feels different, making it infinitely repayable. Terraria isn't just a game to me; it's a journey of endless discovery.

Over the years and years (and years) that I've played this game, I've always heard it compared to other games. Minecraft mostly, but the ones that really get me is when it gets compared to games that vaguely pretend to follow in the footsteps of the greatness we have here. I've played WAY too many "Open world survival craft" games, and every single time, they always leave me bored. The only one I've ever played that retained and deserved the attention it got from me, is this one. This game embraced the format and expounded on it ten fold. So much so that the rest are slop in comparison. Games like Vallheim, The Forest, Green Hell, etc. are fun for a bit, sure, but they always seem to end up at the same exact place. Get x material > make home > get more x material > make x tools > get y material > make y tools so on and so forth. Terraria starts out this way, but after that first hour, instead of becoming the most BORING keyboard rolling grind for the same exact shit, it jumps to being one of the best games I've ever played. You get magic and summoning and crazy swords and super cool bows/arrows and guns/bullets. It becomes a clusterfuck of new enemies and items that you can get from actually fighting mobs while you survive and craft. New and more difficult bosses. New NPCs and new tools to use the INCREDIBLE freedom of expression they give you. Honestly the best part is that every time I stop playing this game, I can come back to it later. It gets huge updates from time to time that add an insane amount of stuff. And on top of that, there's a massive modding community that tosses out some wild stuff. With almost 1k hours, I know there's no way I've experienced everything this game has to offer. If you somehow have gone this long without buying and playing this game, you should. Especially since it goes on sale constantly.

Terraria, a game of creation, variety, randomization, and most of all; pure challenge.

now i do have a few complaints about this game, i grew several pimples on my face from being addicted to this game, and not getting off for a prolonged period of time (usually 6-12 hours a day), my 2nd complaint is that my hand eye coordination has NEVER been better, and my taste in games has gotten so ridiculous. this game is SO good, i was a snob to any other game. especially minecraft, but lets be honest; minecraft sucks. terraria, all the way :3

[h1]Terraria: Journey Never Ends[/h1]
Dig, fight, explore, build- this simple loop is so addicting. It's just fun to venture out into the world, to dig to find ores underground that you use to make weapons, tools, armor, and other life-saving equipment, that turn you from a wimpy little forest dweller— into a big, strong, pull-up-wearing big boy.

This game has its fair share of enemies that the game allows you to pummel with its huge ass selection of weapons. There's consecutively fish as weapons and a book that allows you to literally piss on your foes, many of which you're gonna be using to kill the bosses, the main pillars of progression.

The best part is just constantly finding new shit to do, which I still somehow am. Still I envy whoever the fuck still hasn’t played through this somehow, because the discovery aspect of it all is something I wish I could experience fresh again. You will discover thousands of items, hundreds of enemies, different classes of weapons and armor to choose from, ways to build, and various biomes to explore in, all features that end up leaving games like Minecraft in the dust. There's a little something for everyone, and as with basically every game it's made miles better with friends. Personally it's hard to go back to playing solo with how fun multiplayer can be.

My one complaint about this game is that I wish Master Mode had more 'master' in it. Besides increased enemy health and damage, it would do well with more of an incentive to replay this mode without it being expert mode, but again.

Will check in again at 10,000 hours of playtime when the devs release final update number 10. This game is one of the best out there.

Definitely one of my top 5 games of all time. While the gameplay loop is great by itself, the game has so much more to offer in terms of replayability like expert & master mode that make the game more challenging, secret world seeds that drastically change up how the game is played, and achievements. And to top it all off the developers still clearly care about this game because it gets FREE major content updates at least every year, even when they said they would stop adding content to the game.

This game is one of my all-time favorites! It was purchased by my family somewhere around 2014, and I've played it and replayed it dozens of times since then. 

There is SO much content to be had in this game, with the many bosses to encounter, biomes to explore, and items to obtain. There's building, crafting, mining, and so much more. There's a lot of versatility, where you can progress through the game very quickly or pause to do other things, such as purifying the world evil or making NPC towns all across the map(though fishing is one of my favorite aspects). There is also a lot of visual customization(hair styles, vanity, etc.) especially considering how tiny your character is, so that's fun too. :)

Seriously, this game has so many things to keep you interested, and the developers are still adding more! The replay value is INSANE. Go buy it. Buy it right now.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Very good cinnamon rolls

Ingredients:

For the Dough:

1 cup warm milk (110°F/43°C)
2 large eggs, room temperature
1/3 cup unsalted butter, melted
4 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon salt
1/2 cup granulated sugar
2 1/4 teaspoons active dry yeast (1 packet)
For the Filling:

1 cup packed brown sugar
2 1/2 tablespoons ground cinnamon
1/3 cup unsalted butter, softened
For the Cream Cheese Frosting:

1/4 cup unsalted butter, softened
4 oz cream cheese, softened
1 cup powdered sugar
1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract
Pinch of salt
Instructions:

Prepare the Dough:

In a bowl, combine warm milk and yeast. Let it sit for 5-10 minutes until frothy.
In a large mixing bowl, combine flour, sugar, and salt.
Add melted butter, eggs, and the yeast mixture to the dry ingredients. Mix until a dough forms.
Knead the dough on a floured surface for about 5-7 minutes until smooth.
Place the dough in a greased bowl, cover with a damp cloth, and let it rise in a warm place for 1-1.5 hours, or until doubled in size.
Make the Filling:

In a small bowl, mix together brown sugar and cinnamon.
Roll out the dough on a floured surface into a rectangle.
Spread softened butter over the dough, then sprinkle the cinnamon-sugar mixture evenly.
Roll and Cut:

Starting from one long edge, tightly roll the dough into a log.
Cut into 12 even slices and place them in a greased baking pan.
Second Rise:

Cover the pan with a cloth and let the rolls rise for another 30-45 minutes.
Bake:

Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).
Bake the rolls for 25-30 minutes, or until golden brown.
Make the Cream Cheese Frosting:

Beat together softened butter, cream cheese, powdered sugar, vanilla extract, and a pinch of salt until smooth.
Frost and Enjoy:

Once the cinnamon rolls are out of the oven, let them cool for a few minutes before spreading the cream cheese frosting over them.
Serve warm and enjoy!

Shrek: Once upon a time there was a lovely princess. But she had an enchantment upon her of a fearful sort which could only be broken by love's first kiss. She was locked away in a castle guarded by a terrible fire-breathing dragon. Many brave knights had attempted to free her from this dreadful prison, but none prevailed. She waited in the dragon's keep in the highest room of the tallest tower. For her true love and true love's first kiss.

(Shrek chuckles and rips out a page of the book and closes it)

Shrek: Like that's ever gonna happen. What a load of - (toilet flushes)

("All Star" by Smash Mouth Playing)

(We see an outhouse and hear the sound of a toilet flushing. Out steps Shrek, an ogre, who tugs at his underwear and shakes his foot of the page still stuck to his shoe. He looks lovingly at the swamp he calls home, and goes about his daily routine. Which is taking a mud shower, brushing his teeth with bugs, bathing in a muddy pond, gathering giant slugs for dinner, and painting a warning sign)

(In a nearby village, an angry mob gather up to go after Shrek. At night they gather their torches and pitchforks and enter the swamp, trampling over Shrek's warning signs. Shrek sees them after investigating the commotion, rolling his eyes. The villagers stop outside Shrek's home, unaware that Shrek is sneaking up behind them)

NIGHT - NEAR SHREK'S SWAMP

Villager 1: Think it's in there?

Villager 2: All right. Let's get it!

Villager 1: Whoa. Hold on. Do you know what that thing can do to you?

Villager 3: Yeah, it'll grind your bones for its bread.

(Shrek chuckles, revealing himself to be standing behind the mob)

Shrek: Yes, well, actually, that would be a giant.

(The mob gasps)

Shrek: Now, ogres, oh they're much worse. They'll make a suit from your freshly peeled skin...

(Shrek slowly approaches as the villagers back away in fear)

Villager: No!

Shrek: They'll shave your liver. Squeeze the jelly from your eyes! Actually, it's quite good on toast.

Villager 1: Back! Back, beast! Back! I warn ya!

(The villager waves his torch in Shrek's face. Shrek casually licks his fingers and pinches the flame, extinguishing the torch. The villager drops it)

Villager 1: Right.

(Shrek terrifies the mob with a great frightening roar, his spit extinguishing all the remaining torches. He wipes his mouth and waits for the villagers to stop screaming)

Shrek: (whispering) This is the part where you run away.

Villagers: (gasping)

(Shrek laughs as the men drop their torches and pitchforks and run away as fast they can)

Shrek: And stay out!

(He looks down and picks up a wanted poster dropped by one of the villagers. He reads it aloud)

SHREK: "Wanted. Fairytale creatures"?

(He sighs and walks off. dropping the poster to the ground)

THE NEXT DAY - FOREST

Fairy tale creatures are put in chains and led into wagons by Duloc Guards. The Captain of the Duloc Guards sits at a table paying a line of people their rewards for turning in the fairytale creatures. Those waiting in line include Peter Pan, who is carrying Tinkerbell in a cage, Geppetto who is carrying Pinocchio, and a farmer carrying the Three Little Pigs.

This is one of those games where even if you've played it for over 100 hours you are still looking at the Wiki to figure out how to make an item, where to get an item, how to summon and beat a boss, and what is the most optimal way to organize the living locations of your NPCs, to give some examples. It's quite hard for newbies to get in this game and progress without having to look at the Wiki/youtube tutorials dozens of times, so prepare for that. 

For achievement completionists: You can probably complete all achievements in under 12 hours if you ONLY want to get the achievements and not play through the game the "normal" way. This mostly involves downloading an "All Items" world on Steam workshop and getting the most OP and achievement-related items, then making a new world and blasting through all of the bosses. Most of these achievements aren't very time-consuming to complete on their own using OP items, but some are, such as fully clearing corruption from a world, completing 200 quests for the Angler NPC, and finding all the Town Slimes.

This game is entirely fantastic. From someone that came from the overall monotony of Minecraft's survival mode, here we find a real progression system with varied levels of difficulty and a crafting tree that truly feels like you're accomplishing something. The various bosses and difficulty levels are honestly a far superior experience. Minecraft survival feels mostly pointless. You kill the Ender Dragon and the Wither....and then what? You gain levels.....for what real purpose? You CAN farm Netehrite materials, but you can easily clear "endgame" content without it. You can easily clear endgame content even without enchants. Terraria feels like you need to progressively craft to remain impactful throughout your game experience, and I am thoroughly enjoying myself.

One sentence: Long 'n cheap. This game costs lesser than 5 bucks, and for that amount normally you can't get any good game... Except this one of course. Hundreds of hours of content, infinite replayability and an insane active modding community that's still making amazing mods up to this day. Can you imagine for lesser than 5 bucks you can play a game for hundreds of hours?

The gameplay is smooth and optimized, the game runs amazingly well in both single and multiplayer.

The overall progression is really nice, not forcing the early game player to go one path of things. An example: Instead of being forced to get ore weapons and armor, the player can get various other things to their likings. The player can fight in their unique way to their liking by setting up traps, fighting with their class weaponry or even with falling sand and etc.

Gameplay and difficulty: The mechanics of the game are very simple and easy to learn but a bit hard to master. The game rewards the player for taking risks such as going to the dungeon after defeating a 'certain' boss or even going to hell itself!. Even though all of theese, the difficulty is I think overall a little easy even on Master mode. However the player can activate some secret seeds to make the game WAY harder.

Overall: 10/10, one of the greatest games of all time... Would recommend buying and trying it out for yourself.

[h1]Looking for downsides or traits that might turn you away?[/h1]
[list][*]Takes a lot of time and is very addicting. The amount of content and things to do can be overwhelming, especially for perfectionists.[*]Very combat-centric, even though the combat isn't much deeper than holding LMB until the thing dies. Classes are meaningless, they have mostly the same strategy.[*]Doesn't explain anything — you'll have to rely on a friend or the internet to learn the basics. And you'll be alt-tabbing into the wiki long after that.[*]May be too grindy or difficult for you (generally, more grind = less difficulty in combat). You could play on Journey mode to find your sweet spot if you don't mind the temptation to "cheat".[*]May corrupt/delete your saves because of some issue with Steam Cloud, apparently. This never happened to me, but you might want to make backups manually just in case.[/list]I loved Terraria, but you might not. I'd recommend watching a letsplay or trying it at a friend's place before getting it. And if you do, don't be afraid to play the game your way: mod, cheat through or avoid the parts of gameplay you dislike.

Terraria is often referred to as "2D Minecraft." I wouldn't call it a survival game, but I'm not super sure what to call it. There's a lot more complexity than Minecraft, such as the different weapons, classes, et cetera. There's a lot of variety, and no run would be the same as another. Also, there's a lot more bosses, like a lot a lot more. It's an integral part of the game and its progression, as you can't really do much without defeating them. In Minecraft you don't have to do anything, but in Terraria you have to kill the bosses.
 The pixel-y graphics look super nice and the music slaps.
There's lots of content with weapon variety, seed variety, enemy variety, etc. Practically endless in the core game. However, you can check out TModLoader if you're a little bored with Vanilla.

"Terraria," developed by Re-Logic, is an action-adventure sandbox game that has captured the hearts of millions since its release in 2011. Known for its exploration, crafting, building, and combat in a procedurally generated 2D world, "Terraria" offers players an extensive array of content and activities, making it a standout title in the sandbox genre. This review assesses "Terraria" based on its gameplay mechanics, content variety, graphical and audio presentation, replayability, and overall entertainment value.

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Terraria" excels with its deep and engaging gameplay mechanics, combining elements of exploration, crafting, building, and combat in a seamless manner. The game starts with basic tools, but as players mine resources and battle enemies, they can craft an extensive array of weapons, armor, potions, and other items. The control scheme is intuitive, allowing players to easily navigate the world, manage their inventory, and interact with the environment. The combat system is robust, featuring a wide range of enemies and bosses that require strategy and skill to defeat.

Content Variety
Rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece
One of "Terraria's" most impressive features is its vast content variety. The game boasts hundreds of enemies, bosses, items, weapons, and blocks, ensuring that players always have something new to discover. Biomes ranging from lush forests to desolate underworlds each offer unique resources and challenges. The game also includes events, such as invasions and unique weather phenomena, that add dynamic elements to the gameplay. This wealth of content keeps the game fresh and engaging over countless hours of play.

Graphical and Audio Presentation
Rating: 8/10 - Good
"Terraria's" pixel art style is charming and detailed, contributing to the game's unique identity. The colorful and varied environments, character designs, and creature animations create a vibrant world that's a joy to explore. The audio design, including the game's soundtrack and sound effects, complements the visual presentation well, enhancing the atmosphere and immersion of the game. While the graphics are not technically advanced, their artistic style and consistency add significantly to the overall experience.

Replayability
Rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece
The procedural generation of worlds, combined with the sheer amount of content and different gameplay styles supported, makes "Terraria" highly replayable. Players can experiment with different character builds, engage in building and crafting projects, or challenge themselves with harder difficulty modes. The multiplayer aspect, allowing for cooperative and competitive play, further increases the game's replay value, providing endless opportunities for adventure and creativity with friends.

Overall Entertainment Value
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Terraria" offers an exceptional entertainment value, delivering a rich and immersive experience that appeals to a wide range of players. Whether you're exploring deep caverns, constructing elaborate structures, battling epic bosses, or simply enjoying the creative freedom the game offers, "Terraria" provides a deeply satisfying and fun experience that's hard to match.

Overall Summary and Score
Overall Rating: 9.2/10 - Excellent
"Terraria" stands as a benchmark in the sandbox genre, offering a compelling blend of exploration, crafting, combat, and building set in a dynamic and richly detailed world. Its depth, variety, and charm have earned it a place among the most beloved games of its generation, appealing to both casual gamers and hardcore enthusiasts alike.

"Terraria" has solidified its legacy as a classic, continually updated by its developers with new content and features, ensuring that its magical world remains engaging and fresh for both new players and long-time fans. Its ability to blend various gameplay elements into a cohesive and endlessly entertaining experience is a testament to the creativity and passion of its developers.

Highly Recommended for fans of sandbox games, action-adventure enthusiasts, and anyone looking for a game with deep exploration and creative possibilities. "Terraria" is a masterpiece that offers a world of adventure and creativity waiting to be discovered.

final update: as i claw my way towards 100% completion because i'm an insane person, i want to say that the potential for accidental item mismanagement in this game is absolutely criminal. the times i've had items seemingly vanish from my inventory because either they got sorted to a crate i forgot i had or i didn't click EXACTLY right and dropped the item i was holding while the rest of my inventory was full and then didn't notice it until like an hour later makes me want to puke. basically everything about inventory management in this game is trash and i hate it. there should be an alphabetized inventory manager and a quick-recall button for hoovering up potentially accidental drops.

I recently decided to give Terraria a try, and after 380 hours, let me tell you, it was a colossal disappointment. From the moment I launched the game, I was greeted with outdated graphics that looked like they belonged in the '90s. The pixelated mess of colors was not only an eyesore but also a headache-inducing experience.

The gameplay was an absolute disaster. Navigating through the clunky controls felt like trying to maneuver a tank through a maze. The character movement was sluggish, and the combat mechanics were laughably basic. I expected a modern gaming experience, but Terraria felt like a relic from the past.

The so-called "sandbox" aspect of the game was nothing more than a glorified pixel art project. The world felt empty and lacked any sense of immersion. The lack of a compelling narrative made the game feel like a mindless grind, with no clear goals or objectives to keep me engaged.

To make matters worse, the sound design was unbearable. The repetitive and annoying soundtrack made me want to mute my computer just to escape the auditory assault. I couldn't believe how a game released in this day and age could have such a lackluster and uninspiring audio experience.

Even the community, often touted as one of Terraria's strengths, couldn't save this sinking ship. The fanbase seemed to be stuck in a time warp, clinging desperately to a game that should have been left in the past. The forums were filled with outdated memes and a general lack of helpful information.

In conclusion, Terraria is a game that should be avoided at all costs. Its outdated graphics, clunky controls, lackluster gameplay, and unbearable sound design make it a regrettable waste of time. Save yourself the trouble and invest your gaming hours in something more deserving of your attention.

the best game for people who love combat, building, open world survival, and like every genre of games. spending hundreds of hours is a requirement, and well if your not up for that and all the researching, just play easy and go slow. it's just an amazing game and a obvious classic upon all survival games. if you like minecraft even better! 
one downside is that the game's combat itself relies totally on items and buffs, so if your finding a game that asks for combat skill and controlling skills, this may not be the game for you. mostly grinding and looking at the wiki is just all you do here. but the hours are not regrettable!
another thing i should add, is the end game playthrough. after you finish the final boss; "Moon Lord", you'll be looking forward to about 25 more hours of gameplay and then start to feel the repetitiveness of the game, or feel that the tasks left for you are just way to impossible and boring. still no fear! TModloader is here! TModloader is a additional modding feature in the steam store page you can get for free. which literally increases the whole game's length by an infinite amount of time. my personal fav is "Calamity mode" which also includes more bosses, and WAY too many items added.
i truly recommend you get terraria. grinding is hard, and research is boring. but terraria sure doesn't let you down my mate. anyone will enjoy this game, if provided with the right knowledge, and time.

Review for Achievements:

Most of the achievements are filled with progression, like all the boss slaying ones. The Slayer of Worlds achievement is STILL  glitched so that you can not kill empress of light and queen slime and still get the achievement. The worst ones are easily getting all of the slimes and town NPCs, along with getting the entire world cleansed. (I hated that achievement.) After the progression achievements, you have the ones that are mostly miscellaneous achievements like lucky break, vehicular manslaught and throwing line. Those ones you have a chance of coming across, but sometimes you would have to go out of your way to get. There is one that I thought was not super bad but nobody agrees with, supreme helper minion. As long as you decide to cheese it with journey mode then its not bad. I suggest waiting until post moonlord to do the bucket of bolts achievement, its kind of hard. leading landlord is easy, just move the arms dealer into the desert with the nurse. Unusual survival strategies is just drinking water while drowning. And feast of mitas is eating a cooked golden critter. That's about it for interesting achievements.

What can I say...? 
It's TERRARIA!
(Deep breath...)

You basically can do what you feel like doing with certain difficulties. (For first timers, it may not always be easy depending on your luck.)
It MAY become a BIT of an obsession to do most achievements, but it can be done!

The exploration in this game is possibly the most interesting thing since one world is not the other world alike. you always see different results and biomes. Some worlds even has both the evil ones! (Twice the nightmare....)

And then there is the events. Let's just say it spices up your gameplay. 

At a later stage however, they can be annoying by popping up every so often. Blood Moon & Solar Eclipse are some of the more common ones which occurs one after the other. The only thing you could do if not interested, is to simply (sigh) wait it out. Most likely somewhere in the sky where nothing could spawn.

A bit of advice - Storage is key. It's up to you if you want to make one, but I believe it may be more useful to have one early in the game. Of course I'm writing about the item sorting option, which send the items to treasure chests having the same item in them. It's highly useful imho.

Your adventure may not be the same as others, but it will always interesting in it's own way.

Now go fetch your pickaxe and/or bombs and start aiming for whatever and explore your own world!
It's waiting out there for you. =)

There are a few games that I would call a right-of-passage for all gamers, and this is one of them. Playing Terraria is an absolute blast no matter how you play. The game can be grind heavy at certain points, but as a whole, Terraria never fails to be an excellent experience. 

Here are some of the main reasons why I love this game: the bosses are stellar; the weapons, armors, and accessories are extremely well balanced; the progression is near perfect; the music is iconic; and the difficulty is on point. Plus, this game is infinitely more fun with friends. The level of hilarity that occurred during some of my multiplayer sessions were on another level of fun. 

The only potentially frustrating part of this game is how grind heavy it can get, especially toward the end. Granted, some of the grinding is genuinely fun, but farming enemies for multiple of a rare drop can get tiring after a while. 

If you're unwilling to grind, you could always duplicate the items, but unfortunately, the developers patched out the primary method of duplication (which was actually fairly balanced all things considered).

With that aside, this game is a must-play. If you haven't already bought this game, do it now. I promise, you will not regret it.

This game is among the best I've ever played.
It's managed to hook me over and over and over again, no matter how badly I think I've gotten bored of it. 

The TLDR: JUST BUY IT
However, I will say one thing. If you either don't have an experienced friend to guide you through or are incredibly unwilling to have to use the wiki from time to time, you may have a hard time. Still buy the game, but it would be beneficial if you get some external help as the progression can take a long time to "stumble upon". While 100% possible to beat the game with no spoilers, (most majorly important bosses will be shown to you) it will 100% take longer. Mods are easy to install as these developers are so amazing, they actually went ahead and took unofficial third party software and turned it into semi-official dlc!

Exploration and Creativity: Terraria offers a vast and open world for players to explore, filled with diverse environments, creatures, and resources. The game encourages creativity by providing players with the tools to shape and modify the world to their liking.

Freedom of Gameplay: Terraria doesn't impose a linear progression or a strict set of goals. Players are free to choose their own playstyle, whether it's focusing on exploration, building, fighting, or a combination of these elements. The freedom to play the game in different ways appeals to a broad audience.

Multiplayer Experience: The multiplayer aspect of Terraria enhances the gaming experience. Players can collaborate with friends to explore, build, and defeat challenging bosses together. The cooperative nature of multiplayer adds a social dimension to the game.

Rich Content and Updates: Terraria has received numerous updates over the years, introducing new content, items, biomes, and features. This ongoing support keeps the game fresh and engaging, providing players with a reason to return and discover new challenges.

Boss Fights and Challenges: Terraria features a variety of challenging bosses and events that test players' skills and creativity. Overcoming these challenges is rewarding, and the game offers a sense of progression as players gear up and become more powerful.

Extensive Crafting System: The game's crafting system is intricate and allows players to create a wide array of items, weapons, and tools. The satisfaction of discovering new recipes and crafting powerful gear adds depth to the gameplay.

Pixel Art Style: Terraria's retro-inspired pixel art style has a nostalgic charm that appeals to many players. The simplicity of the graphics doesn't detract from the depth of gameplay and allows the game to run smoothly on a wide range of hardware.

Community and Mods: The Terraria community is active and creative, sharing builds, ideas, and mods. The availability of mods allows players to customize their experience further, adding new content and features to the game.

Accessible on Multiple Platforms: Terraria is available on various platforms, including PC, consoles, and mobile devices. This accessibility makes it easy for players to enjoy the game on their preferred platform.

Let me tel you. This game deservers all of the Positive reviews it gets, and here is why.

I purchased Terraria at release (many many years ago), back then it was already a lot of fun. 
However during the first year of release the developers added so much content. That spans everything from tools, to mobs, to materials, and so much more passive animals and insects that really made the world feel alive and provides so much more immersion and distraction :D .

Fast forward more than 10 years later, And the game is now about a 100X more. In every way. Bosses, Content, tools, progression, materials, events, NPCs, etc.
Also the unique way in which the world transforms as you get super strong for the "original content" of the game, transforming your world to gives you a lot more gameplay and progression than the base game offered. This is when you defeat a boss (at like a 3rd completion of game bosses) and enter the "Hard Mode". Now you have even more things to do, discover, new enemies to fight, resources to gather, new ores, new bosses to defeat, even new biomes in your world. 

Just for the sake of comparison:
I've played Minecraft for a while and I really enjoyed it, however it was always the cense of discovery that made me continue playing. I don't like modding so I just played the vanilla game. However after seeing most of what the game has to offer I kind of just didn't feel like it encouraged me to continue playing. Also with the fact that Mojang/MS add content in such a slow pace it's just insulting at some point.
Here with Terraria, man! oh man! The amount of content is just out of this world.

Yes Terraria is 2D and to be honest after beating the game for the first time, I was kind of done and didn't really feel like creating a new world to explore any further. However now with the super long list of updates and all of the additions to the world. It's just filled with so much to do, see, discover, encounter, and the list goes on. This 2D world is always providing new things from all aspects.

There are literally thousands (yes thousands) of items. the nice thing is that you don't really need to worry about it (at first). You just go and play. You will come across new things and discover how to use them and how to combine them, etc. 
And this just continues stage after stage after stage. 

If you want to decorate your buildings and base. Well you have a world of choice, so many materials to build with, so many decorations, lights and other furniture that you can actually use (uhm Minecraft). 

Best of all! Terraria is also an action game. There are many times you will find a new weapon that will make you feel unstoppable, or just fun to use, or are just super cool/funny/stupid. Some of the weapons at the end game are just crazy.
There are 4 classes as well, you can just pick up any weapon or armour piece so there is no class you need to play. You just use what you have and combine to your desire. All playstyles have plenty of choice when it comes to weapons and man the projectiles or arrows and weapons really become something special when you pass the starting stage of the game making every fight (boss fight) a spectacle like a firework show. Which just makes you want to summon the bosses again and again just for the fun of it.

There is just so much fun to be hand in the combat that it never gets old, so much variety and it's all made with tons of creativity, love and polish that I truly feel that Terraria is one of the best games I've ever played.

One last thing I really want to mentions is the separations between player characters and worlds. For me I don't really like to start a new world because I don't feel like going through the start of the game again.
However with Terraria, as long as the kind of world matches the player character you want to use, you can use any character with any world you have. 
So if you want to start a new world fresh, however do want some of your gear or accessories that make some aspects of the game much easier or faster to do, you can do that. You need a material however don't really want to go hunting for it, just get some from your completed world and craft what you need to continue. Some people don't like that and want to earn everything (even for the 2nd or 3rd time) however the game gives you the choice and let's you play the way you see fit.

Also There is multiplayer which is really a lot of fun, also many online servers that are to this day very active that you can join and play with others or just be a part of a server community.

All that for a super low price that has not changed over the years. No DLC, no in game purchases, And the devs have announced multiple times that they will not make any more updates to the game. Just to continue the development and add a 1000 more items and quality of life features into the game because they love the community so much. 

If you have not yet purchased and played Terraria, There is really no game I can recommend more highly than this one. With the plentiful options you have when creating your many worlds you can make the game as accessible or as hard as you please. So play any way you see fit and enjoy this true masterpiece of a game that is just brimming with quality, fun, creativity, love and adventure!

This game is the bane of my childhood. I've been playing this since 1.2 and its still addicting and has been for years. From the grinding of playing alone, to the end-game experience playing with your friends. I would definitely recommend this game!

A lot of comparisons are made between Terraria and Minecraft, but in reality they are in leagues of their own. This is a game with a robust building system, combat that takes full advantage of being a 2d game, and incredible depth. While it does have some balancing flaws with the higher difficulties, the game is incredible fun and has secrets at all tiers of play.

The main gameplay loop is: Explore A Biome -> Upgrade with the Gear You Find -> Defeat the Newly Available Boss/Event -> Explore the next Biome with a secondary loop of building up a town for your NPC friends (who sell some of the most important gear).

However, at no point is any Biome fully locked off to you (unless it generates mid-game). Sure, the enemies there will punch your face in if you're not ready (and sometimes even if you are) but you can easily sequence break some things given enough luck or skill.

The only major complaint I have is that Summoner needs a bit more gear options, since playing it I felt like I had to skip over several upgrade loops because there simply was no armor option available. I believe there's only 1 metal armor set that has a Summoner option and I also skipped over that. The issue I had because of this is that I never had enough survivability until I got summons that destroyed enemies before they got close, which took a while. The strategy I had to employ was to reroll all of my Accessories into being Warding, which worked decently.

I would say my favorite thing, but it's an incredibly difficult endgame secret, I'll let y'all learn about it for yourself lol.
