Hoo, boy. Another "indie" game from someone who sword to "topple" the "corrupt practices" of companies like EA and Activision, and yet they can't even get the basics of encouraging proper player problem-solving right. Just look at the average "house" for NPCs; boxes of two floors each spread across the world (or one giant box for you OGs) is all that's needed to reach maximum NPC happiness. any sort of creativity, and you run the risk of having to compromise. Same goes with things like beds; good luck having one wedged underneath a single inverted slope block, because apparently that counts as an obstruction for the bed itself, and don't even get me started on Infection; what if Christians like me want to Hallow the world to their holy desires and bring about happiness and joy to all around them? Too bad, the Dryad ain't satisfied until you completely purify the world, and you may have to tear up your entire world just to get that last infected block hiding just out of sight in the midst of the stone and dirt, just like the Dirtiest Block, which is already painstaking to find in and of itself just to have as a pet, not to mention as part of the whole "been here and done everything" end-goal.

And of course, you have to grind CONSTANTLY just to get anywhere substantial in the game itself, and this could take up months' if not years' worth of progress just to get to a point where you can even relax and let loose in your very own world. This is something we could have never been more grateful for in the Game Boy remakes of the original Dragon Quest titles on the NES, which minimized (but not entirely eliminated) grinding, and thus you could just level up and grow stronger as you go and adventure on. This is a terrible practice for any and every game involved, and it all takes away from the whole point of a VIDEO GAME in the first place: something to enjoy, not grind the meat out of down to the bone just to win, even if it means stress and agony, and of course, it's not about the destination, it's about the journey. (And perhaps the biggest irony to all this: the final update to the game is literally named "Journey's End," the ultimate meme to describe all of this.)

If I wanted to play a 2D sandbox survival game, I'd rather be playing MapleStory than what Re-Logic has the nerve to call "one of those to topple the evils of AAA and their diabolical schemes." And besides, the "overwhelming positive" reviews are clearly "sus" to me as well, as I'm pretty sure almost all of their audience was influenced by the internet and how the big guys apparently got into all these so-called "malpractices" and even "criminal acts" rather than really looking into it.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

At this time I have played Vanilla and modded Terraria for a whopping 869 (funny number) hours and while I still enjoy and actively play the game, I can confidently say this is one of the best game I have ever laid a finger on. Much like other popular games such as Dead Cells, Hollow Knight, etc, it is a 2D game that includes parkour and maneuvering yourself around harsh environments. Although there is a lot of jumping, dodging, you can only progress by killing monsters, upgrading your loot, and killing strong, well developed bosses that all have unique attack patterns and well designed sprites to fit their dangerous attacks. Through killing bosses you must gain more loot and climb your way up the food chain to the final boss... the MOON LORD. While many say this is a "rip off Minecraft," they fail to realize that after some trial and error, you learn that there is so much more to it than mining, crafting and speedrunning to the end. Terraria also has a well developed storyline that you are able to explore as you meet new npc's and allow them to move into your home. I highly recommend this game to people who enjoy a little challenge with some unique twists around every corner. I hope this review helped you better your decision as to whether you should buy the game or not and also please have fun!

[b]Introduction:[/b] Ah yes, Terraria, one of the most popular games of all time. I was one of those people who loved this game to death and couldn't stop playing for hours. Despite the ridiculous community still going strong to this day and the absurd amount of time I spent in Terraria, I started to look at this game in a more critical way then an average person. I do want to note, I have talked about Tmodloader before and said that until I gave Terraria a proper review, then Tmodloader would be relevant to talk about in this review since it gives you more to experience and play around with. So today, let's talk about the overwhelmingly positive reception of Terraria and if it is as good as I remember.

[b]Graphics:[/b] Starting off with the graphics, they look really nice along with the details! It's polished yet sweet. 

[b]Music:[/b] The music is solid, of course I've heard the classics, the day time song, the boss fight song, and everybody's favorite song, the wow, wow, wow song, also known as the underground theme, overall, a solid soundtrack.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Terraria plays like a sandbox game, I say sandbox because it's where you'll unleash your creativity, you can build houses, bases, arenas, anything! You also have multiplayer, where you can play with your friends. Within any world you are on, you have the option to explore the world, this can get you some loot, like weapons, potions, accessories, and so on. They're very vital for protecting yourself, why? Because their are enemies out there to kill you, so you must fight and not die. You also have other options to do, like  crafting, fish, play golf, and grind. You explore in a variety of places like grass, desert, ice, ocean, underground, underworld, space, hallow, and underground hallow, these places offer a different look and environment around you. The main goal of this game is to beat the final boss, in order to defeat the final boss, you have to challenge all of the other bosses, like King Slime, Eater of Worlds, and so on! Keep on slaying those bosses, explore your way through this game, until you get to the final boss which is the Moon Lord, slay the Moon Lord and finally, beat the game.

[b]Introduction for the negatives:[/b] Terraria delivers a very solid experience of a game here, it's all fine but then, this is where the fun stops.

[b]Flaws:[/b] Oh my, there are a handful of things wrong with this game, let's look at those graphics again, while yes they're pretty solid at first, the animations...are terrible. There's barely any movement or fascination to be had here, it's especially apparent when fighting a boss, they look very lifeless and static. While the graphics look nice, the animations are very unpleasant, boring, and dull to look at, talk about little effort. The next thing, cheapness, enemies are very frustrating to deal with, especially when trying to work on something or dig, you constantly have to pull out your weapon, kill the enemy, and go back to digging, it's very tedious and annoying, it's worse when exploring because you'll either have to rush to an area where you can get away or risk falling and missing some loot, especially your coins (granted summoner makes this issue non-existent. The worst flaw of all, is the atrocious amount of grinding, that means doing the most tedious and mindless part of the game and you need resources to gear up and fight, which makes the grinding a very time consuming, mindless, tedious, and most boring part of the entire game, oh and don't even get me started on those rare items and making a potion. Combine that with enemies constantly being in your way, luck, and annoying navigation, and you got yourself the peak of a snoozefest here. 

[b]Verdict:[/b] Overall, Terraria is an okay game. To me, it's average at best for a casual and creative experience but at it's worst, the terrible animations, the grinding, boring and frustrating gameplay of Terraria makes it very difficult if not impossible to come back to due to it's flaws. For what it seems, it's obviously overrated, I know I spent a lot of time in Terraria but looking at it in a more critical perspective, I can see why this game is impossible for me to come back to, it's not because I'm bored, it's a general issue that will turn many people off.

[b]Extra:[/b] I didn't forget the extra addition of this game, Tmodloader, I'm not going to cover every mod out there because there are way too many to talk about but i'll give this section a small amount of time. It's basically Terraria but with mod support! Since you can play with mods, it makes Tmodloader slightly better than the original game. You got the more popular mods like Calamity and Thorium, give it a shot if you like, though I will say this, having mod support doesn't erase the game's flaws, it's still full of boring and tedious grinding and gameplay, at least you have some mods that make the grinding less time consuming.

[b]Rating:[/b] 6/10

There isn't such a thing as a "perfect" game but terraria is very close to being exactly that, its a game that can be even compared to masterpieces like Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice, Bloodborne or Deep Rock Galactic just to name a few.

So first off terraria has a comically large amount of content that's able to keep you hooked for days and its so replayable that I completed the game 7 times without getting bored or burned out. So you have completed your first playthrough, what now? Try expert or master mode, too easy for you? Try the Legendary mode and the For The Worthy seed, Already done? Try  100% completing the game or doing a challenge run, you can even install mods that can keep you hooked for even longer that add a sh*t ton of new content like bosses, classes, weapons, post Moon Lord content, difficulty modes and a lot more stuff. These mods include the Calamity Mod, Thorium Mod, Mod of Redemption just to name a few of the best ones. 
I would personally recommend the Ultranium Mod, it doesn't add a lot of content but its quality is off the charts, this mod is quality over quantity, its confusing to download because you cant install it from tmod loader which is goofy as heck. 
But if you're someone that really enjoys vanilla terraria i would recommend the Thorium mod, it doesn't feel like a mod but more like a DLC.
The Calamity Mod is a must play, its so big that it takes a similar amount of space on your computer as terraria itself, its basically a 2nd terraria.

By the way did i forget to tell you that this game is dirt cheap? Its like less than 10 bucks, literally anyone can buy it, and i fu*king swear on god that its worth your time and 10 dollars.

Also the devs aren't pieces of sh*t that don't care about the game and just want to make money, there are zero microtransactions in the game. They actually enjoy working on the game, the devs poured their hearts out to create and update such a masterpiece of a game, although the "final" update was released like a year ago they still constantly update and polish the game.

As I said before the game is very polished, mostly there are no glitches and the few glitches that remain are going to get patched soon or were intentionally kept by the devs because they were so fun/interesting, like the infamous "hoiks".

But for me terraria is more than a game, terraria managed to keep me semi-sane during some of the worst times of my life, i bonded with my old and new friends by playing terraria and some of my favorite content creators are terraria players.

11 out of fu*king 10.

Recommend! ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

In the expansive universe of gaming, Terraria emerges as a masterpiece that defies the ephemeral nature of digital landscapes. Crafted by Re-Logic, this 2D sandbox adventure beckons players into a realm where pixels become portals to boundless creativity and uncharted possibilities. Beyond its visual splendor lies a symphony of emotions, orchestrated by a haunting soundtrack that lingers in the hearts of players, echoing the essence of adventure and discovery. Terraria's beauty lies not just in its meticulously designed landscapes but in the player-driven narrative it fosters. Every pixel, every biome, and every mythical encounter contribute to a story uniquely crafted by each individual adventurer. The game's multiplayer dynamics transcend mere gameplay, transforming Terraria into a social experience that builds lasting connections. Together, players conquer formidable challenges, build whimsical castles, and share laughter in a world that transcends the boundaries of mere entertainment. As we reflect on Terraria's status as a timeless classic, it becomes apparent that its appeal transcends gaming eras. It embodies the human spirit's innate desire for exploration, boundless creativity, and shared adventures. Terraria is not just a game; it is a sanctuary for the soul, where dreams take flight and emotions cascade like waterfalls. In its pixelated landscapes, we discover a timeless magic that leaves an indelible mark on our hearts, evoking tears for the symphony of emotions it has orchestrated across the annals of gaming history.

The updated controller settings are *ABYSMAL*. I bought a copy for my console, as I've quite enjoyed it on my PC over the years. I occasionally used a controller on here, though usually used KB+mouse. I know what the controller settings used to be like, and it all felt very usable. And I have quite possibly never used controls as insanely terrible as on my PS5. I haven't wasted my time determining which version did this, or whether it's possible to somehow downgrade the console's version and leave it that way, such as installing from the disc and keeping the console offline. I shouldn't have to do something like that to do something basic like, y'know, enjoy playing the game. I assume it hasn't been entirely broken on the PC, but maybe it has. I don't even want to launch the game to check I'm so soured by this experience. I cannot possibly imagine what led the developer, after so many years, to butcher a beloved title with such overwhelmingly positive praise. Maybe they want people to quit playing it.

I originally Made a review for this game when I was young in it. I would like to revisit this review and edit it now to add both context and a more helpful volume of information regarding it. 

Lets start at the beginnings, which are so humble. Andrew, my guide, what a sweetheart. I've been able to compare this game to 2D Minecraft originally, but the further you advance in the game, the more you realize that there is so much more to do, and see.  

The depth of this game is already quite extreme, especially for a 2D and I know some of you will say that graphically you just cant do it, and to that, I will say that this is your first mistake. What lacks in natural graphics, it excels in game play, and reliability in that it will be probably one of the best RPG you have ever played. 

Benefits?
1. Bosses that gradually progress harder and harder, but are mandatory requirements to continue onward. Challenging, but ever so rewarding both in items, and feels!

2. Cosmetics.  Who doesn't love a cosmetic? Not just for you, but PETS as well. This could be a winner for a lady in your life, it certainly was a winner for me! 

3. The items and progression system are challenging but fair. You can set up however you like, but you are likely to follow classes, like Warrior, Summoner (my personal favourite), or Mage!

4. If you are a collector, you can bet you will find something to collect in this game. There's 45 toilets you can collect, and they actually benefit you when sitting on them and fishing! 

That's just some of the benefits I like from the game. Some negatives are up to perspective. I had some trouble with latency in some multiplayer worlds, but I cannot blame Terraria, as it could indeed have been my computer at the time. But I would see my friends character in places it wasn't, or rubber banding around me.

Overall, this is a very good game, and to the "Nay Sayers" out there who don't like pixel games, they are all pixels, and it would be a shame for you to miss this gem because of it.

This game is extremely fun!!!
I find it more interactive and progressive than Minecraft because of how much you can do (not making Minecraft look bad), but the feature of playing on the same server with other players, especially friends makes this game so fun for me! I also love the feature of building houses for various NPC's.
Overall, there's much more to do progression wise and its 2D bit animation really adds on to the adventure!
Definitely recommend anyone to play since there are many ways to play Terraria (adventure - my favorite, battle enemies, sell, buy, pets, mining, or making houses for NPC's - also favorite)! 
So far I have only played 12 hours and it's so addicting!

Absolutely love this game, I've sunk over 700 hours into this game and it seems to always have more to discover. The normal mode is quite forgiving, and to the experienced terrarian, probably a little too easy. This being the case, I obviously decided to take on hardcore mode. testing the various levels of world difficulty. after doing so for something like 50 hours of seperate gameplays, I can tell you with 100% certainty that the game WILL kill you. It will suddenly spawn more foe units than you can handle, and make them evade unnaturally well. The game will force units through blocks to get to you. You'll find that even if you're careful to avoid/destroy traps, you'll get either knocked into one by a mob or fall down a hole that doesn't exist until your torch goes away. I love really hard games, but this game isn't hard, it literally forces you dead. (BTW hardcore mode means a single death is final)
If  u say this is 2d minecraft u wrong

If you ever feel saddened by the state of the world, drowned under the weight of responsibility, burdened by the desire to accomplish things that you feel are out of reach - come to Terraria. The joy I get playing this game is almost impossible to describe, the creativity it inspires within me is something truly wondrous. Play this game. I can't say anything that would explain or justify how much this game is amazing. It's cheap, it's got a metric ton of content, you can play it on almost anything, the weapons are awesome, the armour and customisation is fantastic, the graphics are both simple, yet charming - complex, yet stunning. It's art, and like any good art piece, it's best experienced for yourself.

So, what are you waiting for?

Go ahead and try it, as it will change your entire perspective on gaming as a whole.
